commitResults.messageTitle: Added greet() and bye() functions to Clam.java
Added scanner to read user input and echo accordingly
created new Task class, introduced marking functionality

commitResults.messageBody:
Add Text UI Testing via input/output redirection technique to
semi-automate the testing of Clam.

Error handling is currently hard-coded.

Proper error handling will make the code more structured and easier to
update when more features are added and more possible errors arise.

Error handling lets us inform the user what went wrong with their
inputs and helps them to figure out how to use the app properly.

We can streamline error handling using Exceptions, which allows us to
catch exceptions that occur at any point throughout the code.

Clam currently does not allow users to delete items in their task list.

Being able to delete items allows users to correct mistakes or remove
items that they didn't intend to add.

App data does not persist across instances.

Storing user data on their device allows them to keep track of
their tasks even if they have to close the app (e.g. to shut down
their device).

Let's use Scanner and FileWriter to read and write to a text file,
storing the information of each task in a delimited format.

Using a text file to store data is simple and human editable,
which makes it easy to evolve and troubleshoot.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add proper date/time format for data storage
commitResults.messageBody:
Duke currently accepts any string as the input for dates in Deadline
and Event tasks, regardless of whether the string represents a date
in any way.

Change the type that we store it in from String to LocalDate, using
the relevant parsing and printing methods to ensure standardised
storage of info in the text file.

This change of type allows us to make use of the date/time of tasks
in meaningful ways in the future, for example, if we want to view the
tasks in order of due soonest to latest.

commitResults.messageTitle: Organise the codebase using more OOP and packages
commitResults.messageBody:
The codebase is currently disorganised, with most of the logic being
thrown into the main Clam.java file.

Organising the code based on OOP principles helps to compartmentalise
logic, creating a codebase that is easier to expand and evolve. Using
packages also helps us to keep files organised as well.

The enum variables have also been replaced with the Command class and
its respective subclasses, each corresponding to a possible command in
the program. Using an abstract Command class allows to generalise our
execution and allow polymorphism to ensure that the correct logic gets
run for each specific command.

This is done to ensure that our codebase is expandable as we add more
features and more lines of code.
